bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Francis Lee, 1708 September 25

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant Francis Lee, September 25, 1708, that his last letter went by the Carter, and carried a bill of lading for 18 hogsheads of tobacco. He thanks Lee for sending the copies that he had requested, and notes that he now has nothing to do with the affairs of the Wormeley estate and Lee will not hear from him again about them.

div1.head: Robert Carter to Francis Lee, September 25, 1708
div1.p:
My last of 25 of May went by the Carter, brot as I hope bill of Ladin[g for 18]
hogsheads of Tobbacco since I have Yors: by the Fleet wth. the Copys I desired f[or which]
my thanks. The Young Wormeleys have their Estate under their own [direction]
suppose by the directions of their mother, & no doubt You are among thei[r particular?]
Friends, tis time for them to be acquainted with business & I'm clear out [This will]
be the last letter on their Accot.I remain

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Christ Church Parish, Lancaster County, Processioners' Returns, 1711-1783, and Wormeley Estate Papers, 1701-1710, 1716, Acc. 30126, Archives Research Services, Library of Virginia, Richmond, 179.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and state have been added for clarity.
